title: BT increases charges: how to escape the £12 price rise
text:
17.34 -0.45 
Landline rental and call charges will increase from September 20, affecting millions of broadband and phone customers 
BT, Britain's biggest landline and broadband provider, is increasing call charges and line rental fees from September 20, affecting up to seven million customers. 
Citing a multi-billion pound investment in rolling out superfast broadband to homes, BT will increase telephone line rental charges by up to £12 a year and the cost of a 60-minute weekday phone call will be almost 40p higher. 
"We realise customers never welcome price rises," said John Petter, head of BT's customer arm. He added: "We've spent billions rolling out superfast fibre broadband to more than 75pc of the UK." 
We list all the price increases below, including a £1 rise in monthly line rental and a 40p per month increase to BT's international calls package. 
• I complained about poor mobile phone signal and was told 'move to China' • No mobile phone signal? You still have to pay '£800' to escape 
The telecoms giant, which increased its pretax profits by 12pc this year to more than £3bn, is sending letters to affected customers today. 
Existing customers will be given 30 days to leave their contract penalty-free, under new rules introduced by the regulator last month. 
The industry watchdog, Ofcom, now forces providers to let customers walk away from their contracts if they don't deliver what is promised, for example as a result a change in prices or poor signal. 
This also means that customers can escape the price increases by switching broadband providers. Typically customers on older packages tend to pay more and have slower broadband speeds because they don't shop around. 
BT customers typically pay £18 a month for their broadband and £17 for line rental, at a cost of around £420 a year. 
• Cancelling Sky (Other OTC: BSYBF - news ) : regulator to investigate industry's 'aggressive' tactics • The mobile, TV and broadband companies most open to haggling 
By contrast Sky charges £287 for its standard broadband package including line rental, while TalkTalk charges £260. These are savings of £133 and £160 respectively compared with BT. 
Shopping around can come with a catch particularly when firms advertise "free" broadband packages that are actually hugely expensive. 
This is because the companies make up the shortfall for the cheaper deals in other areas, such as line rental and costly call plans. 
Haggle and save £267 
Haggling with your broadband and phone provider can also net a discount. Householders can save up to £267 a year by switching their old broadband subscriptions , according to mystery shopping by Which? last month. 
Successful hagglers save, on average, £14.79 a month on their broadband and TV packages compared with the advertised prices, according to the survey. 
Tips include checking out competitors' deals and mentioning them to sales staff, as well as asking to speak to the "cancellations" department to suggest that you are serious about leaving the firm. 
Existing BT customers who are paying line rental monthly can also save 10pc by paying upfront. 
= Breakdown of the price increases = 
• Line rental: £16.99 a month to £17.99 a month • Line rental "saver" (paying upfront): £183.48 to £194.28 • Call set-up fee: 15.97p to 17.07p • Weekday calls: 9.58p per minute to 10.24p per minute • Unlimited anytime calls on mobile: 6p to 6.41p • Unlimited evening & weekend calls 2014 package is rising to £3.20 • Unlimited anytime calls 2014 package is rising to £7.95 • Friends & family international package: £1.20 a month to £1.25 a month • "International Freedom" package: £6.20 a month to £6.60 a month
